As a result,they decreased lending so that reserves were still higher than the newrequired levels.Friedman and Schwartz view the resulting change in the money supply asindependent because the Federal Reserve was not responding to the real
economy; they inadvertently contracted the money supply because theymisunderstood the motivation of bankers. Further evidence that thecontraction of the money supply was not a conscious decision by the FederalReserve to respond to the real economy is provided by the Minutes of theFederal Open Market Committee for 1937.
